scenarioDescription:
The HD 11964 Exoplanetary System


Overview

HD 11964 is a star with 0.91 times the mass of the Sun, and 2.01 times its radius. It is located 109.38 light years away from the solar system.

HD 11964 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the HD 11964 system


HD 11964 b

HD 11964 b was discovered by the W. M. Keck Observatory observatory, in 2006-07, using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 3.16 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of HD 11964 b is 197.796 times the mass of Earth. The radius of HD 11964 b is 14.100 that of Earth. At more than 50 Earth masses, HD 11964 b is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.


HD 11964 c

HD 11964 c was discovered by the W. M. Keck Observatory observatory, in 2009-03, using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 0.23 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of HD 11964 c is 25.058 times the mass of Earth. The radius of HD 11964 c is 5.380 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, HD 11964 c is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system HD 11964, which contains 2 exoplanets and was discovered by the W. M. Keck Observatory.
name: HD 11964 - System With 2 Exolanets
